Theorem5Sum of subspaces is the smallest containing subspace
Suppose U1,UmU1,Um are subspaces of VV. Then U1++UmU1++Um is the smallest subspace of VV containing U1,,UmU1,,Um.Proof : First it's easy to prove U1++UmU1++Um is a subspace of V. Definition6Direct Sum
Suppose U1,UmU1,Um are subspaces of VV. Then U1++UmU1++Um is called a direct sum if each element of U1++UmU1++Um can be written in only one way as a sum u1+umu1+um, where each ujuj is in UjUj If U1++UmU1++Um is a direct sum, then U1UnU1Un denotes U1+UmU1+Um, with the notation serving as an indication that this is a direct sum.
Example6.1direct sum
Suppose UU is the subspace of F3F3 of those vectors whose last coordinates equal 0, and WW is the subspace of F3F3 of those vectors whose first two coordinates equal 0:U={(x,y,0)F3:x,yF} and W={(0,0,z)F3: zF}.U={(x,y,0)F3:x,yF}andW={(0,0,z)F3:zF}.The F3=UWF3=UW.
 The definition of direct sum requires that every vector in the sum have a unique representation as an appropriate sum. The next result shows that when deciding whether a sum is direct, you only need consider whether 0 can be uniquely written as an appropriate sum.
Theorem7The condition of direct sum
Suppose U1,UmU1,Um are subspaces of VV. Then U1++UmU1++Um is a direct sum if and only if the only way to write 00 as a sum u1++umu1++um, where each ujuj is in UjUj, is by taking each ujuj equal to 00.Proof First suppose U1++UmU1++Um is a direct sum. Then the definition requires 0 can only be represented by one way. Then because each UjUj is a subspace of UU, so it means 0Uj0Uj, thus 0++0=00++0=0 is possible. So the only way to write 0 as a sum is it. If we can write 0 in the only way, then we can't write a vector in two ways:v=u1+um=1+mv=u1+um=1+m Subtracting these two equations, we have0=(u1-1)+(um-m)0=(u1-1)+(um-m) Because 0=0++00=0++0, sou1=1, u2=2,u1=1,u2=2,
 The next result gives a simple condition for testing which pairs of subspaces give a direct sum.
Theorem8Direct sum of two subspaces
Suppose UU and WW are subspaces of VV. Then U+WU+W is a direct sum if and only if UW={0}UW={0}Proof If it's a direct sum, then, there can't be other representation of 0 except 0+00+0. If UW={0,s}UW={0,s}, then because of the addition conservation, there must be a -s-s in WW as well. So there can be another way to represent:0=s+(-s)0=s+(-s) Besides, it's easy to prove that if UW={0}UW={0}, there is only one way to represent 0. Thus Theorem "Condition of direct sum" is satisfied.
More information
The results above only deals with the case of two subspaces. When asking about a possible direct sum with more than two subspaces, it is not enough to test whether U1U2=U1U3=U2U3={0}U1U2=U1U3=U2U3={0}

Definition10Span
 (Some mathematicians also call it linear span)
The set of all linear combination of a list of vectors v1,,vmv1,,vm in VV is called the span of v1,,vmv1,,vm, denoted span(v1,,vm)span(v1,,vm). In other wordsspan(v1,,vm)={a1v1++amvm:a1,,amF}span(v1,,vm)={a1v1++amvm:a1,,amF}The span of the empty list ( ) is defined to be {0}. Besides, we introduce a verb spans. Theorem11Span is the smallest containing subspace
Proof First we show that span(v1,vm)span(v1,vm) is a subspace of VV. The additive identity is in it: set all ai=0ai=0 in equ (1). It's closed under addition It's closed under scalar multiplicationThen we show that spanspan is the smallest subspace Each vjvj is a linear combination of v1,,vmv1,,vm, thus is in the span. Conversely, if we need to contain all vectors in the list, we must allow the addition and scalar multiplication. Thus we must include the span if we want to include all the vectors in the list
 Now we can make one of the key definition in linear algebra!!!
Definition12finite-dimensional vector space
A vector space is called finite-dimensional if some list of vectors in it spans the space.
 Recall that by definition every list has finite length.
Definition13polynomial, P(F)P(F)
A function p:FFp:FF is called a polynomial with coefficients in FF if there exist a0,,amFa0,,amF such thatp(z)=a0+a1z+a2z2++amzmp(z)=a0+a1z+a2z2++amzm for all zFzF. P(F)P(F) is the set of all polynomial with coefficients in FF.
 With the usual operations of addition and scalar multiplication, P(F)P(F) is a vector space over FF. In other words, P(F)P(F) is a subspace of FFFF, the vector space of functions from FF to FF. If a polynomial is represented by two sets of coefficients, then subtracting one representation of the polynomial from the other produces a polynomial that is identically zero as a function on FF and hence has all zero coefficients. Conclusion: the coefficients of a polynomial are uniquely determined by the polynomial.
Definition14degree of a polynomial: deg pdegp
A polynomial is said to have a degree mm if there exist am0am0 such thatp(z)=a0+a1z+amzmp(z)=a0+a1z+amzmfor all zFzF. If pp has degree mm, we write deg p=mdegp=m. The polynomial that is identically 0 is called to have degree --
 In next definition, we use the convention that -<m-<m, which means that the polynomial 00 is in any set of polynomials Pm(F)Pm(F).
Definition15Pm(F)Pm(F)
For mm a non-negative integer, Pm(F)Pm(F) denotes the set of all polynomials with coefficients in FF and degree at most mm.
Example15.1Pm(F)Pm(F) is a finite-dimensional vector space.
Pm(F)Pm(F) is a finite-dimensional vector space for each non-negative integer mm. Note that Pm(F)=span(1,z,,zm)Pm(F)=span(1,z,,zm); here we are slightly abusing notation by letting zkzk denote a function, so zmFFzmFF, and with all the number smaller than mm, they spans a bigger subspace Pm(F)Pm(F) in the vector space FFFF.
However, P(F)P(F) is infinite-dimensional
Example15.2P(F)P(F) is an infinite-dimensional vector space.
Consider any list of elements in P(F)P(F), let mm denotes the highest degree in the list. Then the span of the list cannot represent zm+1zm+1

Definition16Linearly Independence
A list v1,,vmv1,,vm of vectors in V Vis called linearly independent if the only choice of a1,...,amFa1,...,amF that makes a1v1++amvma1v1++amvm equal 0 is a1==am=0a1==am=0. The empty list ( ) is also declared to be linearly independent.
 The reasoning above shows that v1,,vmv1,,vm is linearly independent if and only if each vector in span(v1,,vm)span(v1,,vm) has only one representation as a linear combination of vjvj Now we define Linear Dependent
Definition17Linearly dependent
A list v1,,vmv1,,vm of vectors in V Vis called linearly dependent if it is not linearly independent.
 In other words, a list of vector is linearly dependent if there exist a1,,amFa1,,amF, not all 0, such that a1v1+amvm=0a1v1+amvm=0
Lemma17.1Linear Dependence Lemma
Suppose v1,,vmv1,,vm is a linearly dependent list in VV . Then there exists j{1,2,,m}j{1,2,,m} such that the following hold: vjspan(v1,,vj-1)vjspan(v1,,vj-1) if the jthjth term is removed from v1,,vmv1,,vm, the span of the remaining list equals previous span.The proof is easy. Just change the form of the 0=a1v1++amvm0=a1v1++amvm, and then use other vector in the list to present any of the vjvj
The second lemma above is very useful. It means most time, we can simply add any vector into the list and remove another:
Theorem18Length of linearly independent list length of spanning list
Proof Let the vector in the linearly independent list denoted by ujuj, those in the spanning list denoted by wjwj, up to wnwn. And we do the following steps:(1) Each time, we add a new ujuj into the spanning list, thus we change it into a linear dependent list(2) Then, we remove any wjwj of the list. Because ujuj is independent.Then we create a spanning list of length nn, any other ujuj cannot be linearly independent with this spanning list.
 We can use these theorem to prove some "trivial" true:
Theorem19Finite-dimensional subspaces
Every subspaces of a finite-dimensional vector space is finite-dimensionalProof Let v0=0v0=0. If U=span(v1,,vj-1)U=span(v1,,vj-1), then UU is finite-dimensional. Otherwise, choose a vector vjUvjU such thatvjspan(v1,,vj-1)vjspan(v1,,vj-1)After each step, as long as the process continues, we have constructed a list of vectors such that no vector in this list is in the span of the previous vectors. Thus after each step, the list is linearly independent. By linear independent Lemma, This linearly independent list cannot be longer than any spanning list of VV.
2.B BasesIn the last section, we discussed linearly independent lists and spanning lists. Now we bring there concepts together.
Definition20basis
A basis of VV is a list of vectors in VV that is linearly independent and spans VV.
Theorem21Criterion for basis
A list v1,vnv1,vn of vectors in VV is a basis of V V if and only if every vVvV can be written uniquely in the formv=a1v1++anvnv=a1v1++anvnwhere a1,,anFa1,,anF.
Theorem22spanning list contains a basis
Proof If spanning list is linearly independent, it's a basis Otherwise, remove any vector of it until it's linearly independent.
Theorem23Basis of finite-dimensional vector space
Any finite-dimensional vector space has a basis, because it has some list spanning it.
 Our next theorem is in some sense a dual of Theorem "spanning list contains a basis"
Theorem24Linearly independent list extends to a basis
Every linearly independent list of vectors in a finite-dimensional vector space can be extended to a basis of the vector space.Proof Keep adding additional linearly independent vector into the list, until its length equal to the basis of the space. not formal We can simply add the basis to the independent list, keep removing vectors of it until it becomes a basis. ( Because the vector in previous list v1vnv1vn is linearly independent, so we don't need to remove any vjvj)
 As an application of the results above, we now show that every subspace of a finite-dimensional vector space can be paired with another subspace to form a direct sum of the whole space
Theorem25Every subspace of VV is part of sum equal to VV
A list v1,vnv1,vn of vectors in VV is a basis of V V if and only if every vVvV can be written uniquely in the formv=a1v1++anvnv=a1v1++anvnwhere a1,,anFa1,,anF.
2.C DimensionAlthough we have been discussing finite-dimensional vector space, what's the dimension of such an object? A reasonable definition should force the dimension of FnFn to equal nn. Notice that the standard basis(1,0,,0),(1,0,,0),of FnFn has length nn. Thus we try to define the dimension as the length of a basis. However, before doing this, can we promise that every basis of a vector space has equal length?
Theorem26Basis length does not depend on basis
ProofSuppose VV is finite-dimensional. Let B1B1 and B2B2 be two bases. Then B1B1 is a linearly independent list in the view of B2B2. The length of B2B2 thus must bigger than length of B1B1. And vice versa.
 Now we can formally define the dimension of such spaces:
Definition27dimension, dim VdimV
The dimension of a finite-dimensional vector space is the length of any basis of the vector space.
Example27.1dim Pm(F)=m+1dimPm(F)=m+1
A polynomial has dimension: dim Pm(F)=m+1dimPm(F)=m+1,because the basis is1,z,zm1,z,zm
 To check that a list of vectors in VV is a basis of VV , we must, according to the definition, show that the list in question satisfies two properties. However, sometimes it's easier than this:
Theorem28Linearly independent list of right length is a basis
ProofSuppose dim V=ndimV=n and v1,,vnv1,,vn is linearly independent in VV. The list v1,,vnv1,,vn can be extended to the basis, but basis has length equal nn, thus the list itself is already a basis.
Example28.1Show that list (5,7), (4,3)(5,7),(4,3) is a basis of F2F2
It's easy to show. Just remember that two vector with "," is a list.
 Similarly, we have
Theorem29Spanning list of right length is a basis
ProofSpanning list contains a basis. But all bases have the same length. Thus the list itself is a basis.
 The next result gives a formula for the dimension of the sum of two subspaces of a finite-dimensional vector space. The formula is analogous to a familiar counting formula: the number of elements in the union of two set equals the number of elements in the first set, plus the number of elements in the second set , minus the number of element in the intersection of the two set.
Theorem30Dimension of a sum
If U1U1 and U2U2 are subspaces of a finite-dimensional vector space, thendim(U1+U2)=dim U1+dim U2-dim(U1U2).dim(U1+U2)=dimU1+dimU2-dim(U1U2).ProofLet u1,,umu1,,um be the basis of U1U2U1U2, because u1,,umu1,,um are linear independent vectors in U1U1 and U2U2, we extend them to basis of UiUi. For example, u1,,um,v1,vnu1,,um,v1,vn is a basis of U1U1, u1,,um,w1,wku1,,um,w1,wk is a basis of U2U2. Now we will prove that u1,,um,v1,,vn,w1,,wku1,,um,v1,,vn,w1,,wk is a basis of U1+U2U1+U2. First, it's easy to show that u1,,um,v1,,vn,w1,,wku1,,um,v1,,vn,w1,,wk is a spanning list. Then, if v1v1 is linearly dependent with u1,,um,w1,,wku1,,um,w1,,wk, we can represent v1v1 with this list. According to the addition reservation, v1v1 is a vector of U2U2. Besides, it's a vector of U1U1, so it's in the intersection U1U2U1U2, which means it should be represented by the basis list u1,,umu1,,um. However, we supposed that u1,,um,v1,vnu1,,um,v1,vn is a basis of U1U1, v1v1 cannot be represented by u1,,umu1,,um. So v1v1 must be linear independent with u1,,um,w1,,wku1,,um,w1,,wk So u1,,um,v1,,vn,w1,,wku1,,um,v1,,vn,w1,,wk is a linearly independent list

 Now we can show that no linear map from a finite-dimensional space to a "smaller" space is injective, where "smaller" is measured by dimension

 The term "homogeneous" below means that all the constant value on the right of the equation system equal 0.
Example45.1Rephrase in terms of a linear map the question of whether a homogeneous system of linear equations has a nonzero solution
The equationT(x1,,xn)=0T(x1,,xn)=0means that x1,,xnx1,,xn is in the null space. Thus after rephrasing, the question becomes:Whether the linear map is injective.
Theorem46Homogeneous system of linear equations
A homogeneous system of linear equation with more variable than equations has nonzero solutions.ProofMore variable means it's a mapping into smaller space.
Example46.1Whether an inhomogeneous system of linear equations has no solutions for some choice of the constant terms
If the range has less dimension than vector space WW, then there definitely can be some situation in which the equation has no solution. So the question can be changed as:Whether the linear map is surjective?
Theorem47Inhomogeneous system of linear equations
An inhomogeneous system of linear equation with less variable than equations has no solution for some choice of the constant termsProofMore equation means it's a mapping into bigger space.

Isomorphic Vector SpacesThe next definition captures the idea of two vector spaces that are essentially the same, except for the names of the elements of the vector spaces
Definition54isomorphic, isomorphism
An isomorphism is an invertible linear map Two vector spaces are called isomorphic if there is an isomorphism from one vector space onto the other one.
More information
The Greek word isos means equal; the Greek word morph means shape. Thus isomorphic literally means equal shape. It means the same time as invertible. Use "isomorphism" when you want to emphasize that the two spaces are essentially the same.
Theorem55Dimension shows whether vector spaces are isomorphic
Two finite-dimensional vector spaces over FF are isomorphic if and only if they have the same dimension.Proof First, if vector spaces are isomorphic, then there exists an isomorphic linear map between VV andWW. Suppose AFm,nAFm,n. Then the row rank of AA equals the column rank of AA.Proof Define T: Fn,1Fm,1T:Fn,1Fm,1 by Tx:=AxTx:=Ax. Thus M(T)=AM(T)=A. Now
column rank of A=column rank of M(T)
=dim range T
=dim range T'
=column rank of M(T')
=column rank of At
=row rank of A
columnrankofA=columnrankofM(T)=dimrangeT=dimrangeT'=columnrankofM(T')=columnrankofAt=rowrankofA
